div1.p: Major Kean (Slap) Works (Slap) To Rid Cuba (Slap) of Mosquitoes

div1.head: Newspaper clipping with autographed note, December 17, 1906
div1.p:
MAJOR KEAN (SLAP) WORKS (SLAP) TO
RID CUBA (SLAP) OF MOSQUITOES (SLAP)

Fierce Pests Initiate Army Officer by Attacking Him at His
Own Desk--Specimens Have Eaten Gauze Top Out of
a Jar to Get at Their Enemy.

HAVANA, Cuba. Saturday.--Major Kean,
who came here to fight the pestiferous Cu-
ban mosquito, has met a foe worthy of his
deadliest oil. A swarm of them watching
their chance made a pointed protest
against his operations by attacking him
personally the other day in his office. They
were of the worst breed, too, the yellow
fever kind. but fortunately were not
able to fill him full of anything but bites
and respect. To this fact both the Major
and Captain Thomas, his assistant, who
took part in the battle, owe their exemp-
tion from the list of new cases reported.

It was at the breakfast hour, when all
native assistants had gone out. The head-
quarters of the bug brigade, thus de-
serted, was practically defenceless. No
danger from the enemy entered the
Major's head until he felt it in his legs.

“These fellows are doing splendidly.
After another month you won't be able to
find a--- By George, there is one in
here.” and, rolling up his trousers, he got
down to business on his left ankle.

“One?” yelled Thomas, waving his hands
and slapping his brow. “There are a dozen
around me.”

Getting a microscope when the attack
was fiercest the Major, true to science,
calmly viewed a live bloodthirsty foe.
Then the glass fell to the floor, as he
cried:--“This is a stegomyia. Where do
they come from?”

A brief examination showed how the
fortress of the Board of Health had been
nearly carried. Around on tables were
jars full of wrigglers from all parts of
Havana, that the doctors might, after
their development, learn the location pre-
ferred as a place of residence by the dif-
ferent breeds of parents. The pests, it
was found, had eaten the gauze top out
of the stegomyia jar, and, while they pre-
fer a yellow fever stimulant, they, for-
tunately for the Major and Captain, be-
gan life on plain, simple diet. There is a
lead weight on that jar now and a strong
smell of sulphur in the room.
